DOC.HEAD: Security Increased at Points of Entry, High Risk Targets
DOC.TEXT: Security measures were ordered stepped up Tuesday at Greece's major airports, seaports, border posts and other high-risk targets following recent reports on possible Middle East terrorism. Public Order Minister Dimitris Manikas said the alert was a joint decision made last week by the European Community's security officials, and in reaction to the arrest of suspected Shiite Moslem terrorists in Spain on Nov. 23. In addition, the U.S. State Department sent an advisory Dec. 15 to U.S. embassies expressing its concern that terrorists may be planning near-term attacks against U.S. interests. The increased vigilance was ordered at Greece's airports, frontier posts, seaports, embassies and airline offices. Manikas declined to disclose whether information had been received advising of possible terrorist action in Greece. He said security at Athens International Airport, a hub for Middle Eastern points, was already one of the tightest in the world. Terrorists have struck in Greece several times in the past 10 years. In the most recent incident in July 1988, nine people were killed and 53 injured in a grenade attack aboard a Greek liner as it sailed toward Athens. No one has ever been arrested in the bloody incident but police suspect terrorists of Middle Eastern origin were involved.
